column27: This was my first experience in an international project like this. Even though we had some of our team members not showing up, I feel grateful about getting to know the others who showed up, brainstormed ideas and worked on this with resilience. The event overall was very well- organised. The organisers in the group and the consultation with mentors really helped to boost our confidence and get a well-rounded solution. Thank you for all of their valuable time!

Q13. Briefly describe your overall impressions of this event:
Participating in this hackathon was an incredible experience! It was amazing to work with students from both Florida State University and Taras Shevchenko National University of Kyiv on a real-world challenge. I appreciated how well-organized the event was, with a clear agenda and great mentor support throughout. The collaborative environment really pushed us to think critically and creatively.
column28: I also discovered how open and collaborative my partners from Florida are. They were always eager to share their expertise, support team members, and bring creative solutions to the table. Their strong teamwork and communication skills made the collaboration both productive and enjoyable.

column27: The event was interesting but the selection and participation of teammates was not optimal.
column28: I had difficulty communicating with international partners so I did not learn a lot.

column27: An interesting problem, good participants and mentors, little time
This was a unique experience for my and I was very glad we had a wide range of experts as mentors.
column28: We both enjoy technology and developing our skills

column27: I appreciate the staff and facilitators that worked to organize this event and creat this opportunity.
column28: I learned how similar the KNU students were to me. I also found how there can be friction between different cultures with different expectations that, can result in misunderstandings without proper communication.

column27: I like that there were many facilitators and support from experts, the only thing that got in the way was the first two days of misunderstanding between parts of the team regarding the prototype. After we told the team that we needed to make a prototype, this work was left to me and Kiril. And one member of the team also left us, and we did something with only the knowledge of c# sharp and mathematics

column27: Overall I had a great time at this event. I believe some communication could have been coordinated a bit better and I wish things like time requirements were more strictly enforced across all teams. It was great getting to connect to so many new people and gaining so much new knowledge.
column28: How prevalent the attacks are in Kiev. I knew vaguely because my grandmother lived in Sevastopol, but I didn’t realize how prevalent the airstrikes have been lately. It was also fun to learn the technologies the computer scientists work with over in Kiev!

column27: The overall impression of **Hack Disaster** was highly positive, showcasing innovative solutions to critical challenges. Our project demonstrated the potential of integrating advanced technologies like U-Net, AR, and edge computing for real-world impact. The event fostered creativity, teamwork, and practical problem-solving, leaving participants inspired and motivated to tackle pressing global issues with technology.
column28:
1. Cultural Perspectives in Problem-Solving: Engaging with international students highlighted diverse approaches to tackling challenges, emphasizing how cultural backgrounds influence innovative thinking and collaborative strategies.  

2. Global Applicability of Solutions: Discussions with peers from different countries underscored the importance of designing solutions that address varied regional needs, making our project more inclusive and impactful across global disaster scenarios.
